channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Candelight vigil planned for actor Chadwick Boseman this afternoon at Leimart Park
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: A candlelight vigil is planned for Chadwick Boseman on Saturday afternoon at Leimart Park.
item.content:encoded: A candlelight vigil is planned for Chadwick Boseman on Saturday afternoon at Leimart Park.

media:content.media:description: BEVERLY HILLS,CA --WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 31, 2018--Actor Chadwick Boseman is photographed during a day of promotion for the new Marvel film, "Black Panther," where he plays the title role, at the Montage hotel in Beverly Hills, CA, Jan. 31, 2018. Bozeman made his first appearance as Black Panther in 2016's "Captain America: Civil War." (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Thousands expected to gather in East L.A. to mark anniversary of Chicano Moratorium
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A series of marches, forums and screenings will be held throughout Los Angeles on Saturday to mark the 50th Anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium
item.content:encoded: A series of marches, forums and screenings will be held throughout Los Angeles on Saturday to mark the 50th Anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium

media:content.media:description: A National Chicano Moratorium march against the Vietnam War in East L.A. in 1970.

item.title: When can schools reopen under new state rules? It's all about color-coded tiers and waivers
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Phil Willon
item.description: The majority of California school districts are located in counties with widespread transmission rates and are unable to open under Gov. Gavin Newsom's four-tier system. Elementary schools are still able to seek waivers with county approval.
item.content:encoded: The majority of California school districts are located in counties with widespread transmission rates and are unable to open under Gov. Gavin Newsom's four-tier system. Elementary schools are still able to seek waivers with county approval.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo, left, is given a tour Cerritos Elementary School in Glendale by Principal Perla Chavez-Fritz, right, on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Fired as a hotel housekeeper when she got COVID-19, she now has no income or healthcare
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: For hospitality workers coping with reduced hours and constant worry about exposure, the pandemic is much more than a medical crisis.
item.content:encoded: For hospitality workers coping with reduced hours and constant worry about exposure, the pandemic is much more than a medical crisis.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 26, 2020 - - Arturo Mejia, 30, from left, his wife Liz, 30, holding hens, and their daughters Zoe, 7, and Eva, 5, stand in the backyard of their home where they are growing squash, peppers, tomatoes and herbs in South Los Angeles on August 26, 2020. Liz Mejia was laid off 5 months ago working as a waitress at a restaurant at LAX. Arturo is currently working as a jet mechanic for Delta Airlines. The Mejia family have been saving money by growing their own vegetables and raising hens for eggs. They joined other family members and bought a cow that they had slaughtered for food. They said that they had meat in the house for 3 months. They also had the pet goat slaughtered for meat. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Summer at the Hollywood Bowl, 2020: No concerts but food boxes for the hungry
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: The Hollywood Bowl, its concerts canceled due to the coronavirus, reaches out with music and offers space to help feed the needy.
item.content:encoded: The Hollywood Bowl, its concerts canceled due to the coronavirus, reaches out with music and offers space to help feed the needy.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 27: Aracely Rendon, 42, has her dog "Max" and a friend to keep her company as she waits in line with vehicles lining up early as the Hollywood Bowl has been transformed into a drive-thru food distribution on Thursday's in a season when the concerts are canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The drive-thru food distribution is organized by L.A. County, with major help from the L.A. Regional Food Bank on Thursday mornings where people are able to drive in and get several boxes of food - meat, vegetables, fruit, pantry items - put into the trunks of their vehicles by volunteers or LA County employees who have been re-assigned to help because of a work slow down in their other County positions. Hollywood Bowl on Thursday, Aug. 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Holocaust reparations, prescriptions and rent checks: USPS delays put Americans in jeopardy
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga, Brittny Mejia
item.description: Critical prescriptions are being delayed, placing many Americans' health in jeopardy. New credit cards, rent checks, stimulus payments from the Internal Revenue Service â all have been stalled.
item.content:encoded: Critical prescriptions are being delayed, placing many Americans' health in jeopardy. New credit cards, rent checks, stimulus payments from the Internal Revenue Service â all have been stalled.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE-AUGUST 26, 2020: A mail carrier loads a truck for delivery at a United States Post Office in Torrance on Wednesday, August 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Visiting researcher at UCLA is arrested and charged with destroying evidence
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: An FBI agent alleges that Guan Lei, a researcher at UCLA, destroyed and tried to discard a computer hard drive after being interviewed by investigators.
item.content:encoded: An FBI agent alleges that Guan Lei, a researcher at UCLA, destroyed and tried to discard a computer hard drive after being interviewed by investigators.

media:content.media:description: The seal of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

item.title: Firefighters battle brush fire by Elizabeth Lake
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Firefighters worked Friday afternoon to battle a 150-acre brush fire near Elizabeth Lake.
item.content:encoded: Firefighters worked Friday afternoon to battle a 150-acre brush fire near Elizabeth Lake.

item.title: Orange County wants justices to reopen schools statewide. Experts say it's a long shot
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: The California Supreme Court is considering whether Gov. Gavin Newsom is violating the Constitution by forbidding in-classroom instruction for K-12 schools during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: The California Supreme Court is considering whether Gov. Gavin Newsom is violating the Constitution by forbidding in-classroom instruction for K-12 schools during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: FILE â In this March 12, 2020 file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom speaks to reporters about the state's response to the coronavirus during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat who leads the nation's most populous state, has won praise from both sides of the aisle for his approach to the coronavirus crisis though he's been less aggressive than some other governors and local leaders. Newsom is accompanied by California Department of Public Heath Director and State Health Officer Dr Sonia Angell, left, and California Health and Human Services Agency Director Dr. Mark Ghaly, right. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: California bans flavored tobacco sales in response to a surge in teen use
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Newsom said during a news conference hours before signing the measure that he had long supported a ban.
item.content:encoded: Newsom said during a news conference hours before signing the measure that he had long supported a ban.

media:content.media:description: Menthol cigarettes appear to be more addictive and pose a greater health threat than unflavored tobacco, an FDA report says.

item.title: Here's how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will affect you
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: Here is how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will impact you
item.content:encoded: Here is how California's new coronavirus reopening rules will impact you

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this June 9, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom wears a protective mask on his face while speaking to reporters at Miss Ollie's restaurant during the coronavirus outbreak in Oakland, Calif. According to a new poll, Americans overwhelmingly are in favor of requiring people to wear masks around other people outside their homes, reflecting fresh alarm over spiking infection rates. The poll also shows increasing disapproval of the federal government's response to the pandemic. California is among the states seeing the greatest surge in cases now. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu, Pool, File)

item.title: San Francisco announces plans for outdoor hair and nail services, with outdoor gyms to follow
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco officials say hair salons, barbershops and nail salons may offer services outdoors beginning Tuesday, joining other parts of the state in a measured plan for reopening. Outdoor fitness centers may reopen Sept. 9.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco officials say hair salons, barbershops and nail salons may offer services outdoors beginning Tuesday, joining other parts of the state in a measured plan for reopening. Outdoor fitness centers may reopen Sept. 9.

media:content.media:description: Marathon runners would cross the Golden State Bridge if San Francisco is selected to host the 2024 Olympic Games.

item.title: California lawmakers reach deal for new eviction protections that would last through January
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The plan, which faces the high hurdle of having to get a two-thirds vote in each house of the Legislature by Monday night, was seen as a compromise with landlord groups who oppose a pending bill that would have kept tenants from being evicted if they did not pay any rent as late as April.
item.content:encoded: The plan, which faces the high hurdle of having to get a two-thirds vote in each house of the Legislature by Monday night, was seen as a compromise with landlord groups who oppose a pending bill that would have kept tenants from being evicted if they did not pay any rent as late as April.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 05: A housing rights and anti-eviction protest outside the office of attorney Dennis Block in Valley Village on Tuesday, May 5, 2020, attracted about 35 protesters. Block has evicted more than 200,000 tenants since 1976, according to the AIDS Healthcare Foundation, the parent of nonprofit Housing is a Human Right and Healthy Housing Foundation, the organizers of the protest. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Clancy Imislund, longtime director of L.A.'s Midnight Mission, dies at 93.

item.title: Thief racks up more than $1,400 on credit cards stolen from firefighter, authorities say
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A 37-year-old man has confessed and written an apology for stealing a firefighter's credit cards and racking up more than $1,400 in charges, officials say.
item.content:encoded: A 37-year-old man has confessed and written an apology for stealing a firefighter's credit cards and racking up more than $1,400 in charges, officials say.

media:content.media:description: Brian Johnson, 37, of Live Oak has been arrested on suspicion of stealing a firefighter's wallet earlier this month.

item.title: Newsom unveils sweeping new coronavirus reopening rules for businesses in California
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna, Colleen Shalby
item.description: Newsom takes a more cautious and stringent four-tier approach than his first reopening effort. 'We're going to be more stubborn this time,' he says.
item.content:encoded: Newsom takes a more cautious and stringent four-tier approach than his first reopening effort. 'We're going to be more stubborn this time,' he says.

item.title: California lawmakers vote to expand ban on death penalty for the intellectually disabled

item.description: California legislators vote to expand a law prohibiting the death penalty against intellectually disabled defendants. The bill now goes to Gavin.
item.content:encoded: California legislators vote to expand a law prohibiting the death penalty against intellectually disabled defendants. The bill now goes to Gavin.

item.title: California vs. Trump hits the 100-lawsuit mark with new challenge to environmental rules
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: California reached a milestone Friday in its ongoing legal feud with President Trump when Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra announced he had filed his 100th lawsuit against the administration, this time challenging changes in environmental rules.
item.content:encoded: California reached a milestone Friday in its ongoing legal feud with President Trump when Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra announced he had filed his 100th lawsuit against the administration, this time challenging changes in environmental rules.

media:content.media:description: California Atty. Gen. Xavier Becerra said the state has joined others as a plaintiff in a lawsuit challenging the Trump administration's latest travel ban.

item.title: Mail delivery suspended at L.A. public housing complex with over 1,800 residents
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Mail delivery has been cut off at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, and residents must now collect their mail more than a mile away.
item.content:encoded: Mail delivery has been cut off at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, and residents must now collect their mail more than a mile away.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 18: Daisy Vega, president of the resident advisory council at the Mar Vista Gardens public housing complex, poses for a portrait in front of her apartment in Mar Vista Gardens on Tuesday, Aug. 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. She is worried about a possible change in mail delivery that would stop bringing letters to residents' doors, instead bringing them to centralized banks of mailboxes in the complex. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Preschoolers are mask-licking germ bombs â yet few catch the coronavirus, data show
item.dc:creator: Sonja Sharp
item.description: It's hard to predict what may happen when California's primary schools reopen. But when it comes to the state's youngest students, data are more robust â and more reassuring.
item.content:encoded: It's hard to predict what may happen when California's primary schools reopen. But when it comes to the state's youngest students, data are more robust â and more reassuring.

item.title: LAUSD's liberal student attendance policy raises eyebrows
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Taking attendance at L.A. schools amid online learning is far more complicated -- and a lot more liberal -- than saying "here" when a student's name is called.
item.content:encoded: Taking attendance at L.A. schools amid online learning is far more complicated -- and a lot more liberal -- than saying "here" when a student's name is called.

media:content.media:description: EAGLE ROCK, CA - AUGUST 21: Los Angeles Unified School District Eagle Rock Jr./Sr. High School history teacher Alice Lee interacts virtually with students as they participate in class on the second day of school in LAUSD. Los Angeles on Friday, Aug. 21, 2020 in Eagle Rock, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: 50 years after the Chicano Moratorium, a Mexican American veteran on what it meant to fight in the war
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: He was in Vietnam, a young Mexican American soldier, when thousands of demonstrators marched in East Los Angeles against the war and other injustices.
item.content:encoded: He was in Vietnam, a young Mexican American soldier, when thousands of demonstrators marched in East Los Angeles against the war and other injustices.

media:content.media:description: Rowland Heights, CA, August 24, 2020 - Vietnam veteran Tom Sandoval lived in Lincoln Heights and was in Vietnam during the August 29 Chicano Moratorium march. The National Chicano Moratorium Committee Against The Vietnam War, was a movement of Chicano anti-war activists that built a broad-based coalition of Mexican-American groups to organize opposition to the Vietnam War. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Monopoly, video games, study groups: How COVID-19 is spreading at USC
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Small gatherings, like students studying together and, in one case, playing games like Monopoly, have led to a surge in COVID-19 cases on USC lately.
item.content:encoded: Small gatherings, like students studying together and, in one case, playing games like Monopoly, have led to a surge in COVID-19 cases on USC lately.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 20: USC students Ethan Recinto, 21, of Illinois and Robert Beyer, 21, of New Jersey pose outside University Gateway Apartments on Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. University Gateway has a reputation as a party location and that hasn't changed despite coronavirus.(Josie Norris / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Dangers of third coronavirus surge in California focus on young people, essential workers

item.title: Magnitude 3.5 quake hits near Calexico, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Friday at 4:26 a.m. Pacific time 10 miles from Calexico, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Friday at 4:26 a.m. Pacific time 10 miles from Calexico, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: Heffernan: Kimberly Guilfoyle shows our way of looking at high society and power is broken
item.dc:creator: Virginia Heffernan
item.description: Maybe this century's bipartisan obsession with vulgar preening will be bookended by Guilfoyle's 2004 "New Kennedys" photo and her freeze-frame meme from the 2020 RNC.
item.content:encoded: Maybe this century's bipartisan obsession with vulgar preening will be bookended by Guilfoyle's 2004 "New Kennedys" photo and her freeze-frame meme from the 2020 RNC.

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - AUGUST 24: Kimberly Guilfoyle pre-records her address to the Republican National Convention at the Mellon Auditorium August 24, 2020 in Washington, DC. The novel coronavirus pandemic has forced the Republican Party to move away from an in-person convention to a televised format, similar to the Democratic Party's convention a week earlier. (Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images)

item.title: After 8 workers die of COVID-19, officials want Merced County Foster Farms plant closed

item.title: Officer alleges LAPD had quotas, silenced whistleblowers in gang-labeling scandal
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Ben Poston
item.description: An officer in the LAPD's Metro Division alleges in a lawsuit that commanders have enforced a de facto quota system that rewarded officers who arrested a lot of alleged gang members.
item.content:encoded: An officer in the LAPD's Metro Division alleges in a lawsuit that commanders have enforced a de facto quota system that rewarded officers who arrested a lot of alleged gang members.

item.content:encoded: Orange County is expected to receive the green light for in-person learning at all schools just before Labor Day if the county continues to remain off the state's watchlist.

item.title: Lane Hirabayashi, scholar who refused to let Japanese American prison camps be forgotten, dies at 67
item.dc:creator: Steve Marble
item.description: A UCLA professor and one of the nation's leading authorities on the incarceration of Japanese Americans during World War II, Hirabayashi spent decades keeping memories of the prison camps alive.
item.content:encoded: A UCLA professor and one of the nation's leading authorities on the incarceration of Japanese Americans during World War II, Hirabayashi spent decades keeping memories of the prison camps alive.

item.description: Attorneys for the family of Anthony McClain say he was not armed when police shot him in the back as he ran.
item.content:encoded: Attorneys for the family of Anthony McClain say he was not armed when police shot him in the back as he ran.

item.title: New $300-a-week unemployment benefits coming soon, California officials say
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Millions of Californians who are out of work during the COVID-19 pandemic will soon receive a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit starting retroactive to Aug. 1, state officials said Monday.
item.content:encoded: Millions of Californians who are out of work during the COVID-19 pandemic will soon receive a $300 weekly supplemental unemployment benefit starting retroactive to Aug. 1, state officials said Monday.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Police unions ask Legislature to hold special session for reforms

item.content:encoded: Police unions in Los Angeles and San Francisco Thursday asked Gov. Gavin Newsom to convene a special session of the Legislature before passing new reforms.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 26: A line of people hold their hands up as police form a line in the third street tunnel during a protest following the shooting of Jacob Blake in downtown on Wednesday, Aug. 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Rat poison kills bobcat, mountain lion in Southern California mountains
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: While mountain lions periodically succumb to the poisons, this is the first time in 23 years that a collared bobcat has died directly from the effects of rodenticides, officials say.
item.content:encoded: While mountain lions periodically succumb to the poisons, this is the first time in 23 years that a collared bobcat has died directly from the effects of rodenticides, officials say.

media:content.media:description: The body of B-372, an adult female bobcat, was found June 20, 2020, in Agoura Hills. Officials said she died from the effects of anticoagulant rat poisons.

item.title: Beverly Hills will prosecute protesters for curfew violations
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Beverly Hills is prosecuting 25 people arrested for alleged curfew violations even though L.A. County has declined to take such cases to court.
item.content:encoded: Beverly Hills is prosecuting 25 people arrested for alleged curfew violations even though L.A. County has declined to take such cases to court.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA JUNE 6, 2020-A family member of Breonna Taylor, right, is hugged by another woman after speaking to protestors in beverly Hills Saturday. The protest was organzied by the Refuse Fascism group. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California Senate Republicans under COVID-19 quarantine, not allowed in state Capitol
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez, Taryn Luna
item.description: The state Senate cancels session after Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tests positive for coronavirus. Now he and many GOP lawmakers are under quarantine.
item.content:encoded: The state Senate cancels session after Sen. Brian Jones (R-Santee) tests positive for coronavirus. Now he and many GOP lawmakers are under quarantine.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 28, 2020, file photo, Sen. Holly Mitchell, D-Los Angeles, left, chair of the Senate Budget and Fiscal Review Committee, wears a face mask while standing behind a plexiglass barrier during a budget committee hearing in the Senate in Sacramento, Calif. On Wednesday, July 8, 2020, Secretary of the Senate Erika Contreras announced that, because of an increase in coronavirus cases, the Senate would not return from its summer recess on July 13. The Assembly announced on Monday it would also delay its return after five people who work in the Assembly tested positive for the coronavirus. Speaker Anthony Rendon's Office confirmed Wednesday that number is now at six confirmed cases. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Contra Costa County allows gyms, nail salons and massage services to reopen outdoors
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Though it's still on the state's coronavirus watchlist, Contra Costa County will now allow some personal-care services to operate outdoors.
item.content:encoded: Though it's still on the state's coronavirus watchlist, Contra Costa County will now allow some personal-care services to operate outdoors.

media:content.media:description: WALNUT CREEK, CALIFORNIA - JULY 21: Insignia Hair Salon stylist Regina Muslimova cleans her station after giving a haircut in the parking lot behind her salon on July 21, 2020 in Walnut Creek, California. The salon reopened its doors to clients for haircuts a day after California Gov. Gavin Newsom announced guidance for barbershops and hair salons to offer haircuts in an outdoor setting. According to the new guidelines, "outdoor operations may be conducted under a tent, canopy, or other sun shelter as long as no more than one side is closed, allowing sufficient outdoor air movement." (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: How Los Angeles is commemorating the 50th anniversary of the Chicano Moratorium
item.description: Fifty years after the Chicano Moratorium and the killing of journalist Ruben Salazar, marches, forums, screenings and more show the issues are still relevant.
item.content:encoded: Fifty years after the Chicano Moratorium and the killing of journalist Ruben Salazar, marches, forums, screenings and more show the issues are still relevant.

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by Martina IbÃ¡Ã±ez-Baldor / Los Angeles Times. Photographs from from Los Angeles Times, Los Angeles Herald Examiner, Raul Ruiz, and Special Collections & Archives, John F. Kennedy Memorial Library, Cal State LA, Gloria Arellanes Papers.

item.title: 10 arrested after protesters clash with L.A. police in wake of Jacob Blake shooting
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Richard Winton, Leila Miller
item.description: Several scuffles broke out and 10 people were arrested during a protest in downtown Los Angeles late Wednesday
item.content:encoded: Several scuffles broke out and 10 people were arrested during a protest in downtown Los Angeles late Wednesday

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 26, 2020 - Protesters raise their hands as LAPD officers converge on them from both sides in the Third St. underpass. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California adopts major pollution cuts for diesel trucks and ships
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: California adopts biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade. Rules are equivalent to removing 16 million cars from state roads.
item.content:encoded: California adopts biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade. Rules are equivalent to removing 16 million cars from state roads.

media:content.media:description: SAN PEDRO CA. AUGUST 27, 2020 - Trucks line up to drop off their loads at the Port of Los Angeles in August 28, 2020. California air quality officials are poised to adopt their biggest pollution-cutting regulations in more than a decade, targeting diesel trucks and cargo ships that spew much of the state's cancer-causing and smog-forming emissions. The state Air Resources Board is expected to vote after a public hearing Thursday on two rules: one to establish stringent new emissions standards for heavy-duty diesel trucks and one to reduce pollution from ships docked at ports. (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. teacher flees home amid threats after wearing 'I can't breathe' T-shirt to online class
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: The English teacher at El Camino Real Charter High School fears for her safety and has sought restraining orders after photos of her were shared widely on social media. Students and the teachers union have rallied in her support.
item.content:encoded: The English teacher at El Camino Real Charter High School fears for her safety and has sought restraining orders after photos of her were shared widely on social media. Students and the teachers union have rallied in her support.

media:content.media:description: WOODLAND HILLS, CA - AUGUST 26: Students and community members protest in front of El Camino Charter High School to show support a teacher who wore an 'I can't breathe' shirt while teaching a class on Wednesday, Aug. 26, 2020 in Woodland Hills, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. Zoo reopens, but visitors have to stay one zebra apart
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: The Los Angeles Zoo is open again after closing for 166 consecutive days due to the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles Zoo is open again after closing for 166 consecutive days due to the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Meerkats look at the visitors to the reopening of the Los Angeles Zoo on Wednesday. The zoo had been closed since March 13, 2020 because of the coronavirus pandemic. The reopening conforms with the Los Angeles County Department of Public Health's safety protocols that include limited capacity, timed-ticketed entry, closure of indoor and high-touch spaces, requirements for face coverings and supplemental signage throughout the zoo.

item.title: Dodgers announcer Jaime JarrÃ­n: Chicano Moratorium eyewitness
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: Though he's known for announcing Dodger games in Spanish, Jaime JarrÃ­n was honored for his coverage of the chaos of the Chicano Moratorium.
item.content:encoded: Though he's known for announcing Dodger games in Spanish, Jaime JarrÃ­n was honored for his coverage of the chaos of the Chicano Moratorium.

media:content.media:description: SAN MARINO-CA-AUGUST 18, 2020: Dodger broadcaster Jaime Jarrin, left, and his son Jorge are photographed with their Golden Mike awards for excellence in radio news coverage at home in San Marino on Tuesday, August 18, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Many California police reform efforts have stalled despite push from George Floyd protests
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Among the failed measures was a law that would have required fellow officers to intervene when they witness excessive force.
item.content:encoded: Among the failed measures was a law that would have required fellow officers to intervene when they witness excessive force.

media:content.media:description: BURBANK, CA - JUNE 04: Protest over police brutality and the death of George Floyd takes place in front of North Hollywood Police Station. Rally was organized by Showing up for Racial Justice (SURJ), an organization dedicated to organizing white folks across the nation to show up and fight the root causes of racism. North Hollywood Police Station on Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Burbank, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Through doll play, an L.A. therapist reminds Black girls of their innocence
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: A project in Los Angeles uses doll play to address the phenomenon of "adultification bias," a form of racial prejudice that can lead teachers and other authority figures to treat Black girls as more mature than they actually are.
item.content:encoded: A project in Los Angeles uses doll play to address the phenomenon of "adultification bias," a form of racial prejudice that can lead teachers and other authority figures to treat Black girls as more mature than they actually are.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, California-MARCH 5, 2020: Renee Curry, a therapist, leads a group of Crete Academy students during a therapy session at Crete Academy in Park Mesa Heights. For an hour each Thursday afternoon, the group of four or five girls play with dolls and talk about anything from their home dynamics to their friends at school. The idea is to give these girls a space to experience their own innocence in an attempt to at least partially address the effects of adultification bias (a form of racial prejudice where children of minority groups, particularly black girls, are treated as being more mature than they actually are by a reasonable social standard of development). (Gabriella Angotti-Jones/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Watch the L.A. Times Chicano Moratorium forum live
item.dc:creator: Times staff
item.description: This month the Times published a series of stories revisiting the 1970 Chicano Moratorium and its legacy. Join the discussion.
item.content:encoded: This month the Times published a series of stories revisiting the 1970 Chicano Moratorium and its legacy. Join the discussion.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles Times hosted a virtual community forum Aug. 27 on the Chicano Moratorium, an anti-Vietnam War march held 50 years ago this month that played pivotal role in the fight for civil rights in Los Angeles. Hosted by Times editor Steve Padilla, the forum guests include reporters Daniel Hernandez, former Times reporter Robert Lopez and Carolina Miranda.

item.title: Workers and customers are catching COVID-19. Should businesses escape blame?
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: Businesses fear they'll be blamed for COVID-19's spread. They're fighting for measures to protect them from lawsuits over infections, hospitalizations and deaths.
item.content:encoded: Businesses fear they'll be blamed for COVID-19's spread. They're fighting for measures to protect them from lawsuits over infections, hospitalizations and deaths.

media:content.media:description: COMPTON, CA - AUGUST 12: Henry Ephraim poses for a portrait outside the Ralphs/Food 4 Less distribution center in Compton where he says he caught the coronavirus due to the companies failure to institute safety measures for its workers on Wednesday, Aug. 12, 2020 in Compton, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus has turned once-bustling downtown L.A. into a ghost town. Can it recover?
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: For 10 years, downtown L.A. was booming with a youthful, renegade vibe. The coronavirus puts those hard-won gains at risk.
item.content:encoded: For 10 years, downtown L.A. was booming with a youthful, renegade vibe. The coronavirus puts those hard-won gains at risk.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUG. 6, 2020. A man pushes a shopping cart along the sidewalk in the historc urban core of Los Angeles on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020. Motor and foot traffic downtown has thinned considerably since the pre-coronavirus days of five months ago. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Magnitude 3.5 quake reported near Ukiah, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported at 1:48 a.m. Thursday 13 miles from Ukiah, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported at 1:48 a.m. Thursday 13 miles from Ukiah, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

item.title: Skelton: Newsom proves he's no deer in headlights while managing several crises 'of biblical proportions'
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Now wildfires and blackouts are piled on top of a COVID-19 pandemic â a strange virus that has infected more than 680,000 people and killed more than 12,000 in California. You'd think that might place any governor at political risk, but it apparently hasn't.
item.content:encoded: Now wildfires and blackouts are piled on top of a COVID-19 pandemic â a strange virus that has infected more than 680,000 people and killed more than 12,000 in California. You'd think that might place any governor at political risk, but it apparently hasn't.

item.title: L.A. County CEO to receive $1.5 million and security in settlement over alleged harassment by sheriff
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove, Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Set to retire Monday, L.A. County Chief Executive Sachi Hamai will receive $1.5 million and private security services to address concerns for her personal safety, according to a settlement agreement and a letter sent to county supervisors.
item.content:encoded: Set to retire Monday, L.A. County Chief Executive Sachi Hamai will receive $1.5 million and private security services to address concerns for her personal safety, according to a settlement agreement and a letter sent to county supervisors.

media:content.media:description: LA County agrees to pay $1.5 million to Sachi Hamai after she was harassed by Sheriff Alex Villanueva.

Care's blood drive in downtown Los Angeles on Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The Red Cross recently announced that it had a ``dangerous drop in blood supply'' due to the more than 30,000 blood drives that have been canceled since March because of the COIVID-19 pandemic. item.title: Securing The Times' Pulitzer-winning Latino series for future generations

item.content:encoded: The Times won a Pulitzer for its 1983 project chronicling the lives of Southern California Latinos. It wasn't a part of our digital archive, until now.

media:content.media:description: Images from the Los Angeles Times 1984 Pulitzer Prize Award for Public Service, "Latinos", a 27-part series on Southern California's latino community and culture in the early 1980s. April 3, 1983 Boyle Heights, CA. Old woman at Hollenbeck Park in Boyle Heights. (Los Angeles Times / Jose Galvez)

item.title: An L.A. politico helped select the new postmaster general. Why protesters are at his door
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: John M. Barger is brother to Supervisor Kathryn Barger and a Republican donor. As a Postal Service governor, his life is suddenly filled with complaints and picketers.
item.content:encoded: John M. Barger is brother to Supervisor Kathryn Barger and a Republican donor. As a Postal Service governor, his life is suddenly filled with complaints and picketers.

media:content.media:description: SAN MARINO, CA - AUGUST 22: Protesters rally outside the home of USPS Board of Governors John M. Barger to decry recent U.S. Postal Service cuts by Postmaster General Louis DeJoy that could effect presidential election mail-in ballots on August 22, 2020 in San Marino, California. The protesters say that John Barger, a GOP donor appointed to the Postal Service Board of Governors by President Trump, is responsible for appointing Louis DeJoy to be the Postmaster General. The demonstration is one of many post office rallies spread across the region to reduce the crowd size at any single location because of COVID-19 safety concerns. (Photo by David McNew/Getty Images)

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 21, 2020 -Continental Funeral Home driver Manuel Aguilar handles one of the Covid-19 victims held stored in a mobile refrigerator outside the facility. In the throes of the Covid-19 epidemic Continental struggles to keep up with the demands of rising death rates in a community suffering with health and finances. On this date, they had 112 decedents, 36 of them Covid-19. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: Northern California wildfires rage through the region with possible more on the way
item.content:encoded: Northern California wildfires rage through the region with possible more on the way

media:content.media:description: TOPSHOT - In this long exposure photograph, embers fly off a burning tree during the Hennessey fire in the Spanish Flat area of Napa, California on August 18, 2020. - As of the late hours of August 18, the Hennessey fire has merged with at least 7 fires and is now called the LNU Lightning Complex fires. Dozens of fires are burning out of control throughout Northern California as fire resources are spread thin. (Photo by JOSH EDELSON / AFP) (Photo by JOSH EDELSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Young Black activist's arrest during George Floyd protest in San Luis Obispo sparks a new movement
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: A rally and news conference were held Tuesday for 20-year-old activist Tianna Arata, who was arrested during an antiracism protest last month in San Luis Obispo.
item.content:encoded: A rally and news conference were held Tuesday for 20-year-old activist Tianna Arata, who was arrested during an antiracism protest last month in San Luis Obispo.

media:content.media:description: SAN LUIS OBISPO, CA - AUGUST 25: 20-year-old activist Tianna Arata addresses a rally Tuesday on the steps of the San Luis Obispo County Courthouse as supporters rally to protest her arrest following an anti-racism protest that allegedly ended in car vandalism on July 21, 2020 in San Luis Obispo that has sparked a national outcry. Arata was arrested on multiple felony accounts, but was subsequently released later that evening. The district attorney's office is currently reviewing Arata's case to determine what her charges will be. Her arraignment is set for Sept. 3. Today's rally was hosted by the Free Tianna Coalition, which is backed by BLM co-founder Patrisse Cullors. Courthouse on Tuesday, Aug. 25, 2020 in San Luis Obispo, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Son of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar charged with stabbing neighbor
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Adam Abdul-Jabbar, the son of famed Lakers star Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, faces criminal charges of repeatedly stabbing his neighbor after getting into an argument over trash cans, prosecutors say.
item.content:encoded: Adam Abdul-Jabbar, the son of famed Lakers star Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, faces criminal charges of repeatedly stabbing his neighbor after getting into an argument over trash cans, prosecutors say.

media:content.media:description: CELEBRITY FAMILY FEUD - "Harvey Family Men vs Harvey Family Women and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar vs Ralph Sampson"- The celebrity teams competing to win cash for their charities features Steve Harvey's wife, Marjorie Harvey, leading a team with their sons and sons-in-law, and the other team will be led by Mrs. Harvey's mother and the Harvey daughters. In a separate game, family members from the NBA's all-time leading scorer and six-time NBA champion Kareem Abdul-Jabbar will take on retired NBA Legend Ralph Sampson and his family. This episode of "Celebrity Family Feud" airs SUNDAY, JUNE 25 (8:00-9:00 p.m. EDT), on The Walt Disney Television via Getty Images Television Network.. (Eric McCandless/Walt Disney Television via Getty Images) STEVE HARVEY, KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, ADAM ABDUL-JABBAR, ROSE-ANN SWANN
media:content.media:credit: Eric McCandless/Walt Disney Television via Getty

item.title: Judge denies L.A. County's request to stop Grace Community Church from gathering
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: The evangelical church in Sun Valley has held its weekly Sunday services since July 26, in defiance of state and county health orders. This led L.A. County officials to file a lawsuit against the church.
item.content:encoded: The evangelical church in Sun Valley has held its weekly Sunday services since July 26, in defiance of state and county health orders. This led L.A. County officials to file a lawsuit against the church.

media:content.media:description: Grace Community Church in Sun Valley appears in an image from Google Maps.

item.title: L.A. County COVID-19 cases continue to drop, setting up potential for some school reopenings
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The 14-day average number of coronavirus cases in Los Angeles County has dropped below 200 per 100,000 residents, according to the California Department of Public Health.
item.content:encoded: The 14-day average number of coronavirus cases in Los Angeles County has dropped below 200 per 100,000 residents, according to the California Department of Public Health.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -AUGUST 19, 2020: Gladys Alvarez, a 5th grade teacher at Manchester Ave. Elementary School in South Los Angeles, talks to her students during a meet and greet on Wednesday afternoon. Alvarez was sitting inside her empty classroom while conducting the virtual zoom class. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Feeling anxious and depressed? In California, you're right at home
item.dc:creator: Phillip Reese
item.description: It's official, California: COVID-19 has left us sick with worry and increasingly despondent. And young adults â ages 18 to 29 â are feeling it worst.
item.content:encoded: It's official, California: COVID-19 has left us sick with worry and increasingly despondent. And young adults â ages 18 to 29 â are feeling it worst.

media:content.media:description: Children suffered worse health when their mothers were depressed, a new study has found.

item.title: California moves to stop excessive punishment of Black and disabled students at three districts
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal
item.description: Settlements with districts in Barstow and Oroville follow investigations by the California Department of Justice into discipline of Black and disabled students.
item.content:encoded: Settlements with districts in Barstow and Oroville follow investigations by the California Department of Justice into discipline of Black and disabled students.

media:content.media:description: High school students celebrate the Los Angeles Unified School District's decision to ban student suspensions for "willful defiance."
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: LAPD will keep testing BolaWrap, a device meant to immobilize suspects from a distance
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: L.A. police will continue testing the BolaWrap, a tether restraint designed to help immobilize suspects from a distance, after a pilot program produced too little data.
item.content:encoded: L.A. police will continue testing the BolaWrap, a tether restraint designed to help immobilize suspects from a distance, after a pilot program produced too little data.

media:content.media:description: The BolaWrap devices are about size of a larger cell phone.

item.title: Gov. Gavin Newsom endorses George GascÃ³n in Los Angeles County D.A.'s race
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom endorsed George GascÃ³n on Tuesday in his bid to unseat Jackie Lacey as Los Angeles County's district attorney.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom endorsed George GascÃ³n on Tuesday in his bid to unseat Jackie Lacey as Los Angeles County's district attorney.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2020-2021 state budget during a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., Thursday, May 14, 2020. Reflecting the financial hit California is already seeing from the coronavirus, Newsom proposed cutting $6.1 billion from a variety of programs in a state budget he says prioritizes public education, public health and public safety. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Lobbyist agrees to plea deal in L.A. City Hall corruption case
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Joel Rubin
item.description: Longtime lobbyist and former Los Angeles City Hall official Morrie Goldman has agreed to plead guilty in pay-to-play corruption case.
item.content:encoded: Longtime lobbyist and former Los Angeles City Hall official Morrie Goldman has agreed to plead guilty in pay-to-play corruption case.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles City Ethics Commission has fined lobbyist John Ek $11,000 for inviting city officials to a birthday party at a downtown restaurant.

item.title: 'Significant progress' as weather helps in battle against historic Northern California wildfires
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Leila Miller
item.description: The monster blazes burning across California saw limited growth overnight as firefighters worked to increase containment.
item.content:encoded: The monster blazes burning across California saw limited growth overnight as firefighters worked to increase containment.

media:content.media:description: VACAVILLE, CA - AUGUST 24: The phrase "Vaca Strong" is seen on a burnt out hillside along Pleasants Creek Road where the LNU Lightning complex fire tore through late last week, photographed on Monday, Aug. 24, 2020 in Vacaville, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Island Express sues air traffic controllers in Kobe Bryant crash
item.dc:creator: Nathan Fenno
item.description: Island Express, the company that operated the helicopter involved in the fatal Kobe Bryant crash, blames air traffic controllers for causing accident.
item.content:encoded: Island Express, the company that operated the helicopter involved in the fatal Kobe Bryant crash, blames air traffic controllers for causing accident.

media:content.media:description: EXCLUSIVE: June 17, 2019 - San Diego, California, United States: Sikorsky S76, tail number N72EX, piloted by Ara Zobayan. On January 26, 2020, Kobe Bryant and his daughter Gianna were among nine people on board when this Sikorsky crashed in a Calabasas mountain area killing all passengers and the pilot. (Polaris) ///

item.title: Squaw Valley ski resort to drop 'squaw' from name
item.dc:creator: Hugo MartÃ­n
item.description: Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows, near Lake Tahoe, plans to drop the derogatory term 'squaw' from its name.
item.content:encoded: Squaw Valley Alpine Meadows, near Lake Tahoe, plans to drop the derogatory term 'squaw' from its name.

media:content.media:description: The Olympic rings stand atop a sign at the entrance to the Squaw Valley Ski Resort in Olympic Valley, Calif., July 8, 2020. California's Squaw Valley Ski Resort is considering changing its name to remove "squaw," a derogatory term for Native American women. Squaw Valley President & CEO Ron Cohen says resort officials are meeting with shareholders and the local Washoe tribal leadership to get their input. He says he can't give a timeline on when the decision will be made. The renaming of Squaw Valley Ski Resort is one of many efforts across the nation to address colonialism and indigenous oppression. (AP Photo/Haven Daley)

item.title: FBI assisting in search for L.A. firefighter missing in Mexico
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Francisco Aguilar, a 20-year veteran of the Los Angeles Fire Department, disappeared from his condo in Rosarito, according to family members.
item.content:encoded: Francisco Aguilar, a 20-year veteran of the Los Angeles Fire Department, disappeared from his condo in Rosarito, according to family members.

media:content.media:description: Family members gathered for a vigil to pray for the safe return of a Los Angeles firefighter and Army veteran who disappeared last week in Mexico. Francisco Aguilar, a 20-year veteran of the Los Angeles Fire Department, disappeared from his condo in Rosarit

item.title: The coronavirus gave them jobs â and a new lease on life
item.dc:creator: Doug Smith
item.description: Some just got out of prison; others came off the streets. They are practically unemployable. But thanks to COVID-19, an L.A. nonprofit is able to put them to work at hotels taken over to house the homeless during the pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Some just got out of prison; others came off the streets. They are practically unemployable. But thanks to COVID-19, an L.A. nonprofit is able to put them to work at hotels taken over to house the homeless during the pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 21, 2020 - - Guest services associate Mia Rogers, 23, left, gives Project Roomkey guest Stanley Monk, 58, his lunch under the watchful eye of LVN Richard F. at a Project Roomkey hotel in Los Angeles on July 22, 2020. Rogers, a client of Chrysalis, lost her job due to the coronavirus pandemic. She was hired to work at a Project Roomkey hotel. About 100 clients of Chrysalis, a downtown agency that gets work for homeless people who lost their jobs because of the virus shutdowns. They've been rehired by Project Roomkey to work in hotels. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hope takes flight: L.A.'s Natural History Museum will reopen its Butterfly Pavilion & gardens
item.dc:creator: Deborah Vankin
item.description: The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County will open its Butterfly Pavilion to members starting Aug. 28 and to the public on Sept. 11.
item.content:encoded: The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County will open its Butterfly Pavilion to members starting Aug. 28 and to the public on Sept. 11.

media:content.media:description: An upclose look inside the Butterfly Pavilion
